ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Network traffic characterization, stochastic and deterministic models of network evolution in time, notions of throughput. Scheduling interdependent resources: transmission scheduling of interfering wireless links, combinatorial optimization of the static problem, optimizing continual operation, max-weight scheduling, maximum throughput, scheduling conflicting jobs in shared cloud resources. Multistage service systems and other topics.
I developed some background in network algorithms and understanding of how different network policies work.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - content was very interesting
Weaknesses - poorly organized, syllabus was not really followed at all. 
Homework assignments were often not announced and release dates were not determined in advance
Many lectures were canceled and reschedule to other times that students could not attend live
Final project was released days after originally intended
No textbook or series of resources to formalize knowledge and background information for what was taught in lecture.
No direct comments or feedback on what we did incorrectly on homework assignments
Assumption that everyone was comfortable writing programs without prior warning that this would be a part of the course.
Canvas not really used well
Homework grades and solutions not available in a timely manner

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No - this course was poorly organized, had no solid backing reference material, no active TA participation to help smooth things, and the syllabus wasn't really solid or followed. Although the instructor did try to make the course accessible for those without a specific algorithms background, the course assumed some background in optimization that many students did not have, and thus did not cover how the actual linear programming and optimization topics worked, just on how optimization was applied to different network scenarios. However, the biggest challenge for the course was the instructor's lack of organization, especially in regards to assigning homework and the final project.
